selected_quotes: In the Nansen Ice Shelf, Antarctica, a surface river has been in operation for over a century
Et pendant ce temps là le monde s'écroule ... 😰
La escorrentía superficial de las plataformas glaciales antárticas podría ayudar a su estabilización
Der Film ICE AGE ist real #grosseSorge #climatechange
Voilà un dossier qui devra occuper sérieusement nos dirigeants du monde entier!

citation.abstract: Meltwater stored in ponds and crevasses can weaken and fracture ice shelves, triggering their rapid disintegration. This ice-shelf collapse results in an increased flux of ice from adjacent glaciers and ice streams, thereby raising sea level globally. However, surface rivers forming on ice shelves could potentially export stored meltwater and prevent its destructive effects. Here we present evidence for persistent active drainage networks-interconnected streams, ponds and rivers-on the Nansen Ice Shelf in Antarctica that export a large fraction of the ice shelf's meltwater into the ocean. We find that active drainage has exported water off the ice surface through waterfalls and dolines for more than a century. The surface river terminates in a 130-metre-wide waterfall that can export the entire annual surface melt over the course of seven days. During warmer melt seasons, these drainage networks adapt to changing environmental conditions by remaining active for longer and exporting more water. Similar networks are present on the ice shelf in front of Petermann Glacier, Greenland, but other systems, such as on the Larsen C and Amery Ice Shelves, retain surface water at present. The underlying reasons for export versus retention remain unclear. Nonetheless our results suggest that, in a future warming climate, surface rivers could export melt off the large ice shelves surrounding Antarctica-contrary to present Antarctic ice-sheet models, which assume that meltwater is stored on the ice surface where it triggers ice-shelf disintegration.
citation.title: Antarctic ice shelf potentially stabilized by export of meltwater in surface river

news.title: 빙하 녹은 표면수를 배수시키는 표면 강을 통해 안정화되는 남극대륙 빙붕(Nature)
news.summary: 빙붕의 붕괴는 크레바스 사이에 스며들어서 하이드로 프렉쳐링(hydrofracturing)을 유발하는 빙하가 녹은 표면수에 의해서 지연될 수 있다.

news.title: Antarctica's Vast Network Of Flowing Meltwater More Extensive Than Previously Thought
news.summary: Antarctica's giant ice shelves, which ring the entire continent, act as buttresses and help hold back the land-bound glaciers behind them — glaciers that, if they flow into the ocean, could cause a catastrophic rise in sea levels.

news.title: Verrassend veel vloeibaar water te vinden op Antarctica

news.title: WIRED Awake: 10 must-read articles for April 20
news.summary: Your WIRED daily briefing. Today, Facebook has revealed its secret project for implant-free brain/computer control, Google is reported to be developing an ad blocker for Chrome, Antarctica is crossed by a huge network of rivers and more.

news.title: 融水调节冰架稳定性(Nature)
news.summary: 冰架表面融水会渗入裂缝并重新冻结，造成水压致裂，从而加快冰架的崩塌。在南极半岛的拉森B冰架的崩塌过程中，人们就观测到了上述机制。Robin Bell及同事表明，在南极的南森冰架，一条冰面河已经流淌了一百多年。这条河流最终与一座瀑布相连，它能在一周内排出南森冰架每年产生的所有地表融水。因此，对于南森冰架来说，这种表面排水机制或许阻止了融水破坏冰架的稳定性。研究者目前尚不清楚为什么一些冰架系统保留了融水，而在另一些系统则排出了融水，但这一发现表明，融水可能不是一种普遍性的冰架破坏因素。在本期发表的另一…

news.title: We Just Found Out Antarctica Is Covered in Rivers
news.summary: An enormous waterfall at the Nansen Ice Shelf channels summertime meltwater into the ocean, a process that seemingly protects the shelf from collapse.

news.title: Antarctica Has More Meltwater Streams Flowing Than Thought

news.title: Antarctica's Rivers May Slow Down Its Collapse
news.summary: While Antarctica might appear to be ice, ice, and more ice, a closer look at the South Pole reveals that there is a complex system of running water there.

news.title: Scientists Discover Extensive Network Of Rivers And Lakes Across Antarctica
news.summary: A first of its kind continent-wide survey of Antarctica revealed that the ice-capped continent has a surprisingly vast network of rivers and lakes, which make their way through the ice shelves of the landmass.

news.title: We Just Found Out Antarctica Is Covered In Rivers
news.summary: In 1908, Ernest Shackleton's legendary Nimrod team was making its way toward the South Pole when the men were startled by something unexpected: The sound of liquid water, roaring across the frozen wasteland toward the sea.

news.title: Mayor circulación de agua líquida por la Antártida que lo esperado
news.summary: En el primer estudio de este tipo y de alcance continental, unos científicos han encontrado amplios drenajes de agua procedente de hielo fundido fluyendo sobre zonas de hielo antártico durante el breve verano.

author.name: NCYT - Noticias de la Ciencia y la Technologia

news.title: Primer mapa global de las consecuencias del calentamiento global
news.summary: Un equipo internacional de investigadores ha llevado a cabo el primer mapa global de los principales ríos que llevan agua -procedente del deshielo- desde las grandes masas heladas de la zona continental de la Antártida hasta sus costas.

news.title: We Just Found Out Antarctica Is Covered in Rivers
news.summary: In 1908, Ernest Shackleton’s legendary Nimrod team was making its way toward the South Pole when the men were startled by something unexpected: the sound of liquid water, roaring across the frozen wasteland toward the sea.

news.title: Water streaming across Antarctica surprises, worries scientists
news.summary: In a unique study spanning the entire continent, scientists have found that water is gushing across Antarctica — more than they ever realized.

news.title: Two new studies: Surface of Antarctica 'swimming in meltwater'
news.summary: Print By 3 mins ago in Environment For the first time ever, the network of streams, ponds, and lakes across Antarctica's surface have been mapped, and the extent of the water flow is astounding and worrying to scientists.

news.title: Surface of Antarctica swimming with water
news.summary: Scientists poring over military and satellite imagery have mapped the unimaginable: a network of rivers, streams, ponds, lakes and even a waterfall, flowing over the ice shelf of a continent with an annual mean temperature of more than -50C.

news.title: Antarctica has a network of meltwater rivers that is much larger than previously thought
news.summary: April 24, 2017 —Antarctica is the most inhospitable place on Earth. Since the early 20th century, however, seasonal melting has produced temporary rivers and lakes, breaking up the monotonous line of ice.

news.title: 빙하 녹은 표면수를 배수시키는 표면 강을 통해 안정화되는 남극대륙 빙붕
news.summary: 빙붕의 붕괴는 크레바스 사이에 스며들어서 하이드로 프렉쳐링(hydrofracturing)을 유발하는 빙하가 녹은 표면수에 의해서 지연될 수 있다.

news.title: Opinion | Those menacingly high sea levels may come sooner than we think
news.summary: An aerial view of a massive rift in the Antarctic Peninsula's Larsen C ice shelf.

news.title: Editorial: A faster timetable for rising seas is possible
news.summary: You’ve heard this one before: The Earth is complex and constantly changing, so how can scientists possibly know that burning fossil fuels will do so much harm to the planet? This argument has never been persuasive.

news.title: Cool & Showery - Better Than Average Holiday Weekend Outlook - Urban Tornadoes
news.summary: Downtown Tornadoes - Real Summer Heat On The Way I spend a little time every day trying to clear up weather myths and meteorological misunderstandings.
